{{other uses}} '''Dead air''' is an unintended period of silence that interrupts a [[broadcasting|broadcast]] during which no audio or video program material is transmitted.<ref name=OxfordDefn />
== Radio and television== Dead air occurs in [[radio broadcasting]] when no audio program is transmitted for an extended period of time, usually more than a few seconds. In [[television broadcasting]], the term denotes the absence of both audio and video program material. Technically, a [[carrier wave]] may be still be being transmitted; in radio, the result is silence, and in television, the result is a silent black image.<ref>{{cite web|title=Modulation and Radio Building Blocks: How does modulation work?|url=http://www.taitradioacademy.com/topic/how-does-modulation-work-1-1/|website=Radio Academy|accessdate=7 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite encyclopedia |title= Dead air|encyclopedia=Merriam-Webster's Collegiate® Dictionary, Eleventh Edition (online) |year=2015 |publisher= Merriam-Webster |location= Springfield, MA, USA |url= http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/dead+air |access-date=16 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=OxfordDefn>{{cite encyclopedia |title= Dead air|encyclopedia=Oxford Dictionaries (online) |year=2015 |publisher= Oxford University Press |location= Oxford, OXF, GBR |url= http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/us/definition/american_english/dead-air?q=dead+air | access-date=16 July 2015}}</ref>
Although television directors may use the command "fade to black" or "to black" to indicate a momentary transition to a completely black image,<ref name="Bognar2017">{{cite book|author=Desi Bognar|title=International Dictionary of Broadcasting and Film|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Aqk0DwAAQBAJ&pg=PT48|date=8 September 2017|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-1-136-05401-3|pages=48–}}</ref> the term "dead air" is most often used in cases where program material comes to an unexpected halt, either through operator error or technical malfunction. Among professional broadcasters, dead air is considered one of the worst things that can occur.<ref name="EastmanFerguson2014">{{citation|author1=Susan Tyler Eastman|author2=Douglas A. Ferguson|author3=Robert Klein|title=Media Promotion & Marketing for Broadcasting, Cable & the Internet|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=I5fcAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA128|date=20 June 2014|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=978-1-136-02482-5|pages=128–}}</ref> Moreover, dead air could affect advertising revenue if it affects the airplay of paid commercials.<ref name=":0" />
The term "dead air" does not refer to a broadcast transmitter that is intentionally shut down, i.e. "closed", "signed off" or "[[off the air]]", by a control operator.<ref name="JonesLayer2013">''[https://books.google.com/books?id=K9N1TVhf82YC&pg=PA2007 National Association of Broadcasters Engineering Handbook: NAB Engineering Handbook]''. Taylor & Francis; 26 April 2013. {{ISBN|978-1-136-03410-7}}. p. 2007–.</ref><ref name="Henderson2006">Harry Henderson. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=khWmwVWzu0IC&pg=PA84 Communications and Broadcasting: From Wired Words to Wireless Web]''. Infobase Publishing; December 2006. {{ISBN|978-0-8160-5748-1}}. p. 84–.</ref>
==Broadcast regulations== In the US, dead air, if prolonged and occurring without permission, is an actionable offense that can result in fines from the [[FCC]].<ref name="RBR">{{cite web |title=Maryland radio station punished for silence |url=https://www.rbr.com/maryland-radio-station-punished-for-silence/ |website=Radio & Television Business Report - January 2015 |publisher=Streamline RBR, Inc. |accessdate=30 June 2018}}</ref>
Broadcast stations can use programmable devices known as "silence sensors", "off air alarms" or "silence monitors" that will sound an alarm and alert personnel if dead air persists more than a few seconds.<ref name="Kern2008">Jonathan Kern. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=6UgCBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA339 Sound Reporting: The NPR Guide to Audio Journalism and Production]''. University of Chicago Press; July 2008. {{ISBN|978-0-226-43178-9}}. p. 339–.</ref><ref name="JonesLayer2013" />
==Examples== On September 11, 1987, [[Dan Rather]] walked off the set of the [[CBS Evening News]] when a late running [[U.S. Open (tennis)|U.S. Open]] tennis match threatened to delay the start of his news broadcast. The match then ended sooner than expected but Rather was gone. The network broadcast six minutes of dead air before Rather was found and returned to the studio.<ref name="NYT">{{cite web|last1=Boyer|first1=Peter J.|title=Rather Walked Off Set of CBS News|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/13/nyregion/rather-walked-off-set-of-cbs-news.html|publisher=The New York Times|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=5 February 2018}}</ref> CBS affiliates criticized Rather for the incident.<ref name="LATimes">{{cite web|last1=Sharbutt|first1=Jay|title=Rather Criticized For His Cbs News 'Walkout'|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1987-09-15/entertainment/ca-8170_1_cbs-news-chief|website=The Los Angeles Times|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=5 February 2018}}</ref>
One significant case of dead air occurred during [[Super Bowl LII]] in 2018, when the [[NBC]] television broadcast experienced 26 seconds of dead air during a commercial break. The network blamed "a brief equipment failure",<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/nfl/index.ssf/2018/02/super_bowl_2018_dead_air_5_million_mistake.html|title=Super Bowl 2018: And the most talked-about commercial is ... dead air|last=Campuzano|first=Eder|work=Oregon Live|access-date=2018-02-05}}</ref> and stated that no commercial advertising was lost.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2018/02/04/media/nbc-brief-blackout-super-bowl/index.html|title=NBC blames 'equipment failure' for brief blackout during Super Bowl|last=Stelter|first=Brian|work=CNNMoney|access-date=2018-02-05}}</ref> Prior to [[Super Bowl XLV]], [[Green Bay, Wisconsin|Green Bay]] radio station [[WKZG|WCHK-FM]] announced that it would intentionally go to dead air during the game, since the hometown [[Green Bay Packers|Packers]] were playing in the game.<ref name="ChuckFM">{{cite web |url=http://www.radio-info.com/news/green-bay-packers-fan-chuck-fm-will-play-nothing-during-the-game-sunday| title=Green Bay Packers fan "Chuck FM" will play "nothing during the game" Sunday | last= | first= | work= | publisher=Radio-Info.com | date=2011-02-04 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120108095953/http://www.radio-info.com/news/green-bay-packers-fan-chuck-fm-will-play-nothing-during-the-game-sunday | archivedate=2012-01-08 }}</ref>
When [[United Kingdom|British]] [[Virgin Radio]] host [[Chris Evans (British broadcaster)|Chris Evans]] did not arrive for work on time resulting in Vanessa Feltz filling in for 30 minutes until Evans took the microphone, ''The Guardian'' characterized it as a promotional stunt that forced Feltz "to fill the dead air with jokes".<ref name="TG">{{cite web|title=Chris Evans 'buying a new alarm clock' after tardy arrival for Radio 2 show|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/mediamonkeyblog/2015/jan/21/chris-evans-late-bbc-radio-2-show|website=The Guardian|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=5 February 2018}}</ref>

{{referenced|date=July 2012}} [[Image:Donghuamen Night Market.JPG|thumb|Donghuamen Night Market photo]] '''Donghuamen Night Market''' was a [[night market]] located in the northern end of [[Wangfujing]] in [[Beijing]], China. Dong Hua Men is written 东华门, the name of the East Gate of the Forbidden City.
==Description== One can find a row of unusual food stalls. An array of [[Chinese cuisine|Chinese food]] delicacies are on display with people bustling around to experience some new tastes. Items such as sheep's particular parts, offal soup, [[Deep frying|deep fried]] crickets, centipedes, silk worms, scorpions and lizards are available to eat on a stick. There are also the more widely recognised Western foods such as [[spring roll]]s, [[dumplings]], [[crab cakes]] and candy fruit. All stalls display their food selections in both Chinese (Mandarin) and English. The food was displayed raw and can be deep fried in a large Wok upon request.
==Closure== Due to hygiene and noise complaints, the Donghuamen market closed on 24 June 2016.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/travel/news/article.cfm?c_id=7&objectid=11660489|title=Infamous Beijing bug market to close|newspaper=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|agency=[[Australian Associated Press]]|date=21 June 2016}}</ref>

{{good article}} {{Use Australian English|date=January 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox song | name = Elastic Heart | cover = Sia - Elastic Heart from The Hunger Games single cover.png | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Sia Furler|Sia]] featuring [[The Weeknd]] and [[Diplo]] | album = [[The Hunger Games: Catching Fire – Original Motion Picture Soundtrack]] | released = {{ubl|{{Start date|2013|10|1|df=yes}} {{small|(soundtrack)}}|9 January 2015 {{small|(Sia album promotion)}}}} | format = [[Music download|Digital download]] | recorded = | studio = | venue = | genre = {{hlist|[[Electropop]]|[[Pop music|pop]]|[[Trap music (EDM)|trap]]}} | length = {{Duration|m=4|s=18}} | label = {{hlist|[[RCA Records|RCA]]|[[Republic Records|Republic]]|[[Lionsgate Films|Lionsgate]]}} | writer = {{hlist|[[Sia Furler]]|[[Diplo|Thomas Wesley Pentz]]|[[Djemba Djemba|Andrew Swanson]]}} | producer = {{hlist|[[Diplo]]|[[Greg Kurstin]]}} | chronology = [[Sia Furler|Sia]] | prev_title = [[She Wolf (Falling to Pieces)]] | prev_year = 2012 | next_title = [[Battle Cry (Angel Haze song)|Battle Cry]] | next_year = 2014 | misc = {{Extra chronology | artist = [[The Weeknd]] | type = single | prev_title = [[Live For]] | prev_year = 2013 | title = Elastic Heart | year = 2013 | next_title = [[Wanderlust (The Weeknd song)|Wanderlust]] | next_year = 2014 }} {{Extra chronology | artist = [[Diplo]] | type = single | prev_title = [[XXX 88]] | prev_year = 2013 | title = Elastic Heart | year = 2013 | next_title = [[Take Ü There]] | next_year = 2014 }} {{External music video|{{YouTube|KWZGAExj-es|"Elastic Heart"}}}} }} "'''Elastic Heart'''" is a song by Australian singer [[Sia Furler|Sia]], featuring Canadian singer [[The Weeknd]] and American record producer [[Diplo]], taken from [[The Hunger Games: Catching Fire – Original Motion Picture Soundtrack|the soundtrack]] for the 2013 American film ''[[The Hunger Games: Catching Fire]]''. [[Djemba Djemba|Andrew Swanson]] assisted the artists in writing the song, with production handled by Diplo and American producer [[Greg Kurstin]]. It was released on 1 October 2013 as a [[Single (music)|single]] from ''Catching Fire'' by [[RCA Records|RCA]], [[Republic Records|Republic]] and [[Lionsgate Films|Lionsgate]]. "Elastic Heart" peaked at number 7 on the [[Record chart|singles chart]] of New Zealand and was [[List of music recording certifications|certified gold]] by the [[Recorded Music NZ]]. It also appeared on the charts of Australia, Belgium, Switzerland and the United Kingdom. In 2014, Sia re-recorded a solo version of "Elastic Heart" for her sixth studio album ''[[1000 Forms of Fear]]''. The solo version was released in 2015 as a single from the album and was accompanied by a controversial [[music video]] that features actor [[Shia LaBeouf]] and dancer [[Maddie Ziegler]]. The clip was the eighth most viewed YouTube music video in 2015, while the single peaked within the top 10 in Australia and the United Kingdom, and the top 20 in the United States. ==Release and composition== {{Listen |filename = Sia, The Weend, Diplo - Elastic Heart (sample).ogg |title = "Elastic Heart" (2013) |description = "Elastic Heart" is a [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]] and [[Trap music (EDM)|trap]] song which talks about the protagonist's strength after a breakup. |format = [[Ogg]] |pos = left}} "Elastic Heart" was released as the second single from [[The Hunger Games: Catching Fire – Original Motion Picture Soundtrack|the soundtrack]] for ''[[The Hunger Games: Catching Fire]]'' (2013). The song was made available for [[Music download|digital download]] on 1 October 2013. It was sent to US [[rhythmic contemporary]] radio by [[RCA Records]], [[Republic Records]] and [[Lionsgate Films]] on 8 October 2013.{{cite web |url=http://www.allaccess.com/top40-rhythmic/future-releases |title=Top 40/R Future Releases |publisher=All Access Music Group |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6K3LVxFXm?url=http://www.allaccess.com/top40-rhythmic/future-releases |archivedate=1 October 2013}} A [[sentimental ballad|power ballad]],{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/review/accidental-pop-songwriter-sia-doesnt-quite-reclaim-206353|title=Accidental pop songwriter Sia doesn't quite reclaim solo career momemtum|work=[[The A.V. Club]]|first=Annie|last=Zaleski|date=8 July 2014|accessdate=24 January 2015}} Hilary Hughes of ''[[The Village Voice]]'' named "Elastic Heart" a "grand, full [[electropop]] production,"{{cite web |url=http://blogs.villagevoice.com/music/2015/01/sia-snl-review.php |title=You Don't Have to 'Get' Sia to Love Her on 'SNL' |date=18 January 2015 |first=Hilary |last=Hughes |work=[[The Village Voice]] |accessdate=20 February 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6XHbjzMY5?url=http://blogs.villagevoice.com/music/2015/01/sia-snl-review.php |archivedate=25 March 2015 |df= }} while Aimee Cliff from ''[[Fact (UK magazine)|Fact]]'' characterised the song as "a [[Pop music|pop]] song that bounces like rubber." Meanwhile, ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' reviewer Julianne Shepherd called it a [[Trap music (EDM)|trap]] song.{{cite journal|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/albumreviews/1000-forms-of-fear-20140708|title=Sia 1000 Forms of Fear: Album Review|work=Rolling Stone|first=Julianne|last=Shepherd|date=8 July 2014|issue=1212|accessdate=24 January 2015}} Its lyrics address "the overwhelming strength Sia needed to convince herself that life was worth living after coming out of a crushing relationship." Having the [[chord progression]] of D–A–E–F♯m, the song is composed in the key of [[A major]].{{cite web|url=http://www.musicnotes.com/sheetmusic/mtdFPE.asp?ppn=MN0134936|title=Sia 'Elastic Heart' Sheet Music|accessdate=18 April 2015|publisher=Musicnotes.com}} ==Reception== Blue Sullivan of ''[[Slant Magazine]]'' wrote that "'Elastic Heart' is a seamless and highly successful team-up that reads like a grimier after-market version of [[Lady Gaga]]'s '[[Do What U Want]]'."{{cite web|url=http://www.slantmagazine.com/music/review/original-soundtrack-the-hunger-games-catching-fire/6 |title=Original Soundtrack: The Hunger Games: Catching Fire |first=Blue |last=Sullivan |publisher=[[Slant Magazine]] |date=24 November 2013 |accessdate=1 June 2014}} ''[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]'' magazine's Chris Martins stated that "Sia soared" and it was a "bubbling ballad,"{{cite web|url=https://www.spin.com/2013/09/sia-the-weeknd-diplo-elastic-heart-hunger-games-catching-fire/ |title=Sia Soars With the Weeknd and Diplo on 'Elastic Heart' |first=Chris |last=Martins |work=[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]] |date=30 September 2013 |accessdate=1 June 2014}} and Bradley Stern of [[MuuMuse]] claimed it was "a perfectly chaotic combination."{{cite web|url=http://www.muumuse.com/2013/09/sia-elastic-heart-the-weeknd-diplo-hunger-games-catching-fire.html/ |title="Elastic Heart (feat. The Weeknd & Diplo)": Sia Soldiers On With Almighty 'Hunger Games' Anthem |first=Bradley |last=Stern |publisher=MuuMuse |date=September 2013 |accessdate=1 June 2014}} "Elastic Heart" debuted at number 67 on the Australian [[ARIA Charts|ARIA Singles Charts]] on the chart issue dated 14 October 2013. The single also charted at number 27 on the Walloon [[Ultratip]], and number 36 in Switzerland. The song fared better in New Zealand, peaking at number 7 on the national singles chart and was [[List of music recording certifications|certified gold]] by the [[Recorded Music NZ]] (RMNZ). In the United Kingdom, "Elastic Heart" debuted at number 79 on the [[UK Singles Chart]] on 12 October 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.zobbel.de/cluk/131012cluk.txt|title=Chart Log UK: New Entries Update – 12.10.2013 (wk 40)|publisher=Zobbel Archive|accessdate=20 January 2015}} On 17 January 2015, the single re-entered the chart at number 61.{{cite web|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/singles-chart/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150111192826/http://www.officialcharts.com/singles-chart/|title=Official Singles Chart UK Top 100 – 17th January 2015|publisher=[[Official Charts Company]]|archivedate=11 January 2015}} ==Credits and personnel== {{div col}} * [[Songwriting]], lead vocals – [[Sia Furler]], [[Diplo|Thomas Wesley Pentz]], [[Andrew Swanson]] * [[Record producer|Producing]] – [[Greg Kurstin]], [[Diplo]] * [[Audio engineering|Engineering]] – Greg Kurstin * Additional engineering – Alex Pasco * Vocal recording – Rob Kleiner * [[Audio mixing|Mixing]] – Manny Marroquin * Additional mixing – Chris Galland, Delbert Bowers * [[Audio mastering|Mastering]] – Brian "Big Bass" Gardner * [[Drum]] [[Audio programming|programming]] – Andrew Swanson, Diplo {{div col end}} Credits for "Elastic Heart" are adapted from ''The Hunger Games: Catching Fire'' soundtrack digital inlay cover.{{cite AV media notes|title=[[The Hunger Games: Catching Fire – Original Motion Picture Soundtrack]]|others=Various artist|publisher=[[Republic Records]], a division of [[Universal Music Group]]|year=2013|type=digital inlay cover}} ==Charts and certifications== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} ===Weekly charts=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! The Weeknd & Diplo) |publisher=Radio Airplay SRL |language=Italian |accessdate=10 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140820002144/http://www.radioairplay.fm/RadioDate/PublicDetails/41529/ |archivedate=20 August 2014 |df=dmy }} |} ==Sia solo version== {{Infobox song | name = Elastic Heart | cover = Sia - Elastic-Heart, 2015.png | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Sia Furler|Sia]] | album = [[1000 Forms of Fear]] | released = {{Start date|2015|1|9|df=y}} | format = [[Music download|Digital download]] | recorded = | studio = | venue = | genre = {{hlist|[[Electropop]]|[[Pop music|pop]]|[[Trap music (EDM)|trap]]}} | length = {{Duration|m=4|s=17}} | label = RCA | writer = {{hlist|Sia Furler|[[Diplo|Thomas Wesley Pentz]]|[[Andrew Swanson]]}} | producer = {{hlist|[[Diplo]]|[[Greg Kurstin]]}} | prev_title = [[You're Never Fully Dressed Without a Smile#Sia cover|You're Never Fully Dressed Without a Smile]] | prev_year = 2014 | next_title = [[Déjà Vu (Giorgio Moroder song)|Déjà Vu]] | next_year = 2015 | misc = {{External music video|{{YouTube|KWZGAExj-es|Official music video}}}} }} In 2014, Sia recorded a solo version of "Elastic Heart" for her sixth [[studio album]], ''[[1000 Forms of Fear]]''.{{cite AV media notes|title=[[1000 Forms of Fear]]|others=[[Sia (musician)|Sia]]|publisher=[[RCA Records|RCA]]/Monkey Puzzle|type=liner notes}} It was released on 9 January 2015 by [[RCA Records|RCA]] as the third single from the album. Annie Zaleski from ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' labelled "Elastic Heart" a "striking power ballad," while [[AllMusic]]'s Heather Phares picked the song as one of the three standouts from the album, alongside "[[Chandelier (Sia song)|Chandelier]]" and "[[Eye of the Needle (song)|Eye of the Needle]]".{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/1000-forms-of-fear-mw0002680594|title=1000 Forms of Fear – Sia {{!}} Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|first=Heather|last=Phares|accessdate=9 January 2015}} Aimee Cliff from ''Fact'' named it a "great example of how only Sia can truly rock a song written for (rather than by) Sia."{{cite web|url=http://www.factmag.com/2014/07/16/1000-forms-of-fear/|title=1000 Forms of Fear – FACT magazine|work=[[Fact (UK magazine)|Fact]]|date=16 July 2014|first=Aimee|last=Cliff|accessdate=9 January 2015}} The deluxe version of ''1000 Forms of Fear'' includes a piano version of the song. In Italy, "Elastic Heart" impacted [[contemporary hit radio]] on 9 January 2015. "Elastic Heart" debuted at number 8 on the [[ARIA Charts|ARIA Singles Chart]] on the chart issue dated 19 January 2015.{{cite web|url=http://ariacharts.com.au/chart/singles |title=ARIA Australian Top 50 Singles Chart |publisher=[[ARIA Charts]] |accessdate=24 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140322200515/http://ariacharts.com.au/chart/singles |archivedate=22 March 2014 |df=dmy }} The following week, the song rose to number 5. The [[Australian Recording Industry Association]] certified it 3× [[List of music recording certifications|Platinum]], which denotes shipments exceeding 210,000 copies in Australia.{{cite web|url=http://ifpi.org/content/library/international-award-levels.pdf |title=International Certified Awards |accessdate=2014-05-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140328112251/http://ifpi.org/content/library/international-award-levels.pdf |archivedate=28 March 2014 |df= }} In the United States, "Elastic Heart" debuted at number 17 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] on the issue chart dated 24 January 2015, becoming the week's "Hot Shot Debut".{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/6443523/hot-100-chart-moves-sia-video-controversy|title=Hot 100 Chart Moves: Video Controversy Sends Sia's 'Elastic Heart' to No. 17 Debut|first=Gary|last=Trust|date=16 January 2015|work=Billboard|accessdate=24 January 2015}} The song was later certified double platinum for combined sales and streaming of 2 million units in the United States. In the United Kingdom, the single peaked at number 10 on the [[UK Singles Chart]] on 5 April 2015 and has since been certified Platinum by the [[British Phonographic Industry]]. ===Music video=== [[File:Elastic Heart video.jpg|thumb|left|A still from the video featuring Shia LaBeouf and Maddie Ziegler]] On 7 January 2015, the music video for the song was released. Directed by Sia and [[Daniel Askill]], shot by cinematographer Sebastian Wintero and choreographed by [[Ryan Heffington]], the video features [[Maddie Ziegler]], who previously appeared in the video for Sia's single "[[Chandelier (Sia song)|Chandelier]]" and "[[Big Girls Cry]]", and actor [[Shia LaBeouf]].{{cite web|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/entertainment/news/sias-elastic-heart-music-video-shia-labeouf-underwear-201571|title=Sia's "Elastic Heart" Music Video Features Shia LaBeouf in Underwear, Dance Moms' Maddie Ziegler: Watch Now!|first=Rachel|last=McRady|work=[[Us Weekly]]|date=7 January 2015|accessdate=9 January 2015}} In the video, Ziegler and LaBeouf wear nude and dirt-smeared outfits.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/news/sia-responds-to-criticism-for-elastic-heart-video-that-sees-shia-labeouf-wrestle-with-a-12yearold-9964392.html|title=Sia apologises for 'Elastic Heart' music video that sees Shia LaBeouf wrestle 12-year-old Maddie Ziegler|work=[[The Independent]]|first=Jess|last=Denham|date=8 January 2015|accessdate=11 January 2015}} Justine Harman from ''[[Elle (magazine)|Elle]]'' likened the concept of the video to the plot of ''[[Titanic (1997 film)|Titanic]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.elle.com/culture/news/a21988/sias-new-video-plot-of-titanic/|title=Sia New Video – Maddie Ziegler, Shia LaBeouf, Titanic|work=[[Elle (magazine)|Elle]]|accessdate=9 January 2015|date=7 January 2015|first=Justine|last=Harman}} Jason Lipshutz from ''Billboard'' summarised: "The entirety of the video features the surprising pair interpreting the song through various body contortions: they dance-fight, collapse in the middle of the cage, crawl toward and away from each other, and make some wildly fantastic facial expressions."{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop-shop/6429587/sia-elastic-heart-video-maddie-ziegler-shia-labeouf|title=Sia's 'Elastic Heart' Video is a Cage Match Between Maddie Ziegler & Shia LaBeouf|date=7 January 2015|work=Billboard|first=Jason|last=Lipshutz|accessdate=11 January 2015}} The video was nominated for the [[2015 MTV Video Music Awards|2015 VMA Award]] for Best Female Video.[http://www.mtv.com/ontv/vma/2015/best-female-video/ "Best Female Video"], MTV, July 21, 2015 ''Billboard'' selected the video as one "of the 10 best music videos of 2015 (so far)",Lipshutz, Jason. [https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop-shop/6605833/2015-10-best-music-videos-taylor-swift-maroon-5-sia "The 10 Best Music Videos of 2015 (So Far)"], Billboard, June 24, 2015 as did ''PopCrush'', commenting that the video's "lopsided choreography and filthy warfare yields a raw, junkyard beauty that doesn’t ask who will make it out alive, but whether escape is ever really on the table."Donnelly, Matthew. [http://popcrush.com/best-music-videos-2015-so-far/ "The Best Music Videos of 2015 (So Far!): Sia, 'Elastic Heart'"], PopCrush, May 28, 2015 ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' magazine's Vulture.com ranked it number 6 on its list of 2015's top 10 music videos.Lockett, Dee. [http://www.vulture.com/2015/12/10-best-music-videos-of-2015.html# "The 10 Best Music Videos of 2015"], Vulture.com, December 15, 2015 As of November 2018, the video had received more than 970 million views on YouTube.Furler, Sia. [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KWZGAExj-es "Sia – Elastic Heart feat. Shia LaBeouf & Maddie Ziegler (Official Video)"], YouTube: SiaVEVO, January 7, 2015, accessed March 9, 2018 It was the eighth most viewed YouTube video in 2015.Spanos, Brittany. [https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/2015s-10-most-viewed-music-videos-on-youtube-20151209 "2015's 10 Most Viewed Music Videos on YouTube"], ''Rolling Stone'', December 9, 2015 ====Controversy==== The video "courted controversy and plaudits in equal measure", with some commentators perceiving it to have [[pedophilia|pedophilic]] undertones because it features an adult and child dancing together clad only in beige dancewear.Norton, Siobhan. [https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/health-and-families/features/ballet-fitness-why-growing-numbers-are-using-plis-and-pirouettes-to-work-out-10386434.html "Ballet fitness: Why growing numbers are using pliés and pirouettes to work out"], ''The Independent'', July 14, 2015[https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/jan/11/sia-video-pop-music-not-paedophilia?CMP=soc_567 "Sia's video: let's be wary of seeing paedophilia everywhere"], ''[[Guardian Australia]]'', January 11, 2015 Sia explained that the two dancers represented "warring 'Sia' self states," but she apologized on Twitter to anyone who was upset by the video:{{cite web| url=https://gma.yahoo.com/sia-apologizes-pedophilia-perception-music-video-133650931--abc-news-music.html |title=Sia Apologizes for ‘Pedophilia’ Perception in Music Video |publisher=Yahoo! |date=January 9, 2015 |accessdate= March 8, 2015}}Ranscombe, Siân. [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/rockandpopfeatures/11585580/The-10-most-controversial-music-videos.html "The 10 most controversial music videos"], ''The Telegraph'', May 10, 2015
I anticipated some "pedophelia!!!" Cries for this video. All I can say is Maddie and Shia are two of the only actors I felt could play, these two warring 'Sia' self states. I apologize to those who feel triggered by "Elastic Heart". My intention was to create some emotional content, not to upset anybody.{{cite web| url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/music/sia-sorry-over-pedophilia-upset-caused-by-elastic-heart-video-20150108-12kabs.html| title=Sia sorry over 'pedophilia' upset caused by Elastic Heart video|date=8 January 2015| work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|first=Peter|last=Vincent|accessdate=9 January 2015}}
