Name !! Author !! Year !! class="unsortable"|Description |- |- |''Autumn: Aftermath'' || [[David Moody|Moody, David]]||2012||The final book in the Autumn series |- |''Autumn: The City'' || [[David Moody|Moody, David]]||2003||The second novel in the Autumn series begins by introducing new characters whose actions run concurrent with the action in the original novel, before uniting the two groups. |- |''Autumn: Disintegration'' || [[David Moody|Moody, David]]||2011||A continuation of the Autumn series |- |''Autumn: The Human Condition'' || [[David Moody|Moody, David]]||2005||A continuation of the Autumn series |- |''Autumn: Purification'' || [[David Moody|Moody, David]]||2004||The third novel in the Autumn series revolves around a military bunker sealed off from the outside world. |- |''The Awakening''||[[Brett McBean|McBean, Brett]]||2012|| A coming-of-age novel concerning a teenager’s tumultuous summer as he deals with the joys and hardships of growing up, while learning about the value of freedom at the hands of a kind but cursed old man. Contains strong elements of traditional Haitian Vodou and zombies. |- |''[[Breathers: A Zombie's Lament]]'' || [[S. G. Browne|Browne, S. G.]]||2009||A dark, comedic take on zombies told from the point of view of a recently reanimated corpse. |- |''[[Cell (novel)|Cell]]''|| [[Stephen King|King, Stephen]]||2006||Anyone talking on a cell phone after a particular event becomes an aggressive, bloodthirsty zombie.{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Cell Review from Pickerington Public Library| work =| publisher =[[Publishers Weekly]]| date =2006-01-02| url =http://www.supportlibrary.com/nl/br.cfm?re=890&url=%40nl_bookview.cfm%3Fx%3D890%26bn%3D%252A%252E%252E%2520%2522P%2524O%2520Z%255D3%255DI0%2520%2520%250A| archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20081201071518/http://www.supportlibrary.com/nl/br.cfm?re=890&url=%40nl_bookview.cfm%3Fx%3D890%26bn%3D%252A%252E%252E%2520%2522P%2524O%2520Z%255D3%255DI0%2520%2520%250A| dead-url =yes| archive-date =2008-12-01| format =| doi =| accessdate =2008-08-28}} |- |''[[City of the Dead (novel)|City of the Dead]]''||[[Brian Keene|Keene, Brian]]||2005||This is the official followup to ''[[The Rising (Keene novel)|The Rising]]''. Demons possess the bodies of the dead, including animals. One man attempts to reach his son. |- |''[[The Dead (Higson novel)|The Dead]]''||[[Charlie Higson|Higson, Charlie]]||2010|| A young adult novel. Adults over sixteen turn to zombies and young survivors battle against them. |- |''Dead City''||[[Joe McKinney (author)|McKinney, Joe]]||2006|| Battered by five cataclysmic hurricanes in three weeks, the Texas Gulf Coast and half of the Lone Star state is reeling from the worst devastation in history. A deadly virus has broken out, returning the dead to life. |- |''[[Dead of Night (zombie novels)|Dead of Night]]''||[[Jonathan Maberry|Maberry, Jonathan]]||2011|| A prison doctor injects a condemned serial killer with a formula designed to keep his consciousness awake while his body rots in the grave. But all drugs have unforeseen side-effects. Before he could be buried, the killer wakes up. Hungry. Infected. Contagious. This is the way the world ends. Not with a bang...but a bite. |- |''[[Dead Sea (novel)|Dead Sea]]''||[[Brian Keene|Keene, Brian]]||2007|| A zombie apocalypse starts with undead rats emerging from Baltimore's sewers. |- |''[[Deadline (Grant novel)|Deadline]]''||[[Mira Grant|Grant, Mira]]||2011|| A continuation of ''[[Feed (Grant novel)|Feed]]''. |- |''[[Death Troopers]]''||[[Joe Schreiber|Schreiber, Joe]]||2009|| A story in the [[Star Wars universe]] about an Imperial prison ship stranded in space, encountering another ship crammed with the ship's crew, which have been turned into zombies due to a bio-weapon the ship was carrying. |- |''[[The Enemy (Higson novel)|The Enemy]]''||[[Charlie Higson|Higson, Charlie]]||2009|| A young adult novel. Surviving youngsters battle adults who have become zombies. |- |''[[The End (Higson novel)|The End]]''||[[Charlie Higson]]||2012|| A post-apocalyptic young adult horror novel and the seventh book in a planned seven-book series, titled ''The Enemy''. |- |''[[The Fallen (Higson novel)|The Fallen]]''||[[Charlie Higson]]||2013|| A post-apocalyptic young adult horror novel and the fifth book in a planned seven-book series, titled ''The Enemy''. |- |''[[The Fear (Higson novel)|The Fear]]''||[[Charlie Higson|Higson, Charlie]]||2011||A young adult novel. Surviving youths battle "mothers" and "fathers" who have fallen ill. |- |''[[Feed (Grant novel)|Feed]]''||[[Mira Grant|Grant, Mira]]||2010|| News reporters blogging in a world that survives a zombie apocalypse. |- |''[[The Forest of Hands and Teeth]]'' || [[Carrie Ryan|Ryan, Carrie]] ||2009||Teen book. In a village generations after the zombie apocalypse a 16-year-old struggles with her town's religious rules until the village walls are breached and she is forced to flee into the woods.{{cite news| url=http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/09146/972132-44.stm| work=[[Pittsburgh Post Gazette]]| title=Zombies Rise in Teen Lit |accessdate=2009-08-08 | date=2009-05-26}} |- |''[[Friday the 13th (franchise)|Friday the 13th]]: The Jason Strain'' || [[Christa Faust|Faust, Christa]] ||2006|| An attempt at replicating the immortality and healing factor of [[Jason Voorhees]] goes wrong, and results in a zombie plague. |- |''[[Charlie_Higson#The_Enemy_short_story|Geeks vs. Zombies]]''||[[Charlie Higson]]||2012|| A companion short story book in ''[[The Enemy (Higson novel)|The Enemy]]'' series portrays an exclusive scene from ''[[The Fear (Higson novel)|The Fear]]'' (2011), on World Book Day. |- |''[[Generation Dead]]'' || [[Daniel Waters (novelist)|Waters, Daniel]] ||2008||Teen book. In the present day, U.S. teens are randomly rising from the dead, and the country is in turmoil over the question of zombie civil rights. |- |''[[The Girl with All the Gifts]]'' || [[Mike Carey (writer)|M.R. Carey]] ||2014|| In a [[Dystopia|dystopian]] future, most of humanity is wiped out by a fungal infection. The infected quickly lose their mental powers and feed on the flesh of healthy humans. |- |''[[Handling the Undead]]''|| [[John Ajvide Lindqvist|Lindqvist, John Ajvide]]||2005||During a massive heatwave the unexplained resurrection of thousands of recently deceased people begins in [[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]]. David, whose wife has recently died, has gone to the morgue to identify remains of his lost love only to find that she has begun to move. It's terrifying to David, but gives him a strange kind of hope. |- |''[[Herbert West--Reanimator]]'' || [[H.P. Lovecraft|Lovecraft, H.P.]] || 1921 || Medical doctor invents a serum that re-animates corpses. |- |''History is Dead: A Zombie Anthology'' || [[Kim Paffenroth|Paffenroth, Kim (editor)]] || 2007 || Twenty short stories by twenty different authors with zombies in alternate histories. |- |''[[The Hunted (Higson novel)|The Hunted]]''||[[Charlie Higson]]||2014|| A post-apocalyptic young adult horror novel and the sixth book in a planned seven-book series, titled ''The Enemy''. |- |''Husk'' || [[Corey Redekop|Redekop, Corey]] || 2012 || A blackly humorous take on the genre, as an unwilling but terribly hungry zombie strives to continue his career as an actor. |- |''[[Illuminatus!]]''|| [[Robert Shea|Shea, Robert]] and [[Robert Anton Wilson|Wilson, Robert Anton]] ||1976||In the third volume, ''Leviathan'', opens with a rock festival on the shores of Lake Totenkopf in Bavaria. Unknown to all except the heroes and the villains, the bodies of an entire division of the [[Waffen-SS]] were interred on an underwater plateau supported by a "biomystical field" to maintain bodily integrity. At the climax of the festival, they will return to life as zombies, surface, and slaughter all 250,000 hippies at the festival. |- |''Kiss of Life'' || [[Daniel Waters (novelist)|Waters, Daniel]] ||2009||Teen book. Sequel to ''[[Generation Dead]]''. |- |''The Living Dead 2'' || [[John Joseph Adams|Adams, John Joseph]] || 2010 || A collection of 44 short stories about zombies includes contributions by [[Max Brooks]], [[Robert Kirkman]], and [[David Wellington (author)|David Wellington]]. |- |''[[Monster Island (Wellington novel)|Monster Island]]''|| [[David Wellington (author)|Wellington, David]] ||2006||In New York City, the dead walk the streets. From the other side of the planet, a small but heavily-armed group of schoolgirls-turned-soldiers comes in search of desperately needed medicine, with a former UN weapons inspector as their local guide. |- |''[[Monster Nation (novel)|Monster Nation]]''||[[David Wellington (author)|Wellington, David]] ||2006|| A prequel to ''Monster Island'' where a sentient zombie tries to cure herself. |- |''[[Monster Planet (novel)|Monster Planet]]''||[[David Wellington (author)|Wellington, David]] ||2007|| Sentient zombies are intent on taking over the world killing the living with a nuclear weapon. |- |''Les morts ont marché''|| [[:fr:Mathieu Fortin|Mathieu Fortin]] ||2011|| In Saint-Liconet, a zombie outbreak took place. To try finding who was the first living dead among the eight last suspects, you read interviews with witnesses, autopsy reports, and proofs analysis reports. |- |''[[Necromancer (novel)|Necromancer]]''||Harper, Scott ||2009||| Sequel to ''Predators or Prey?''. Monster hunter Wendy Markland fights zombies in the Pine Barrens of New Jersey. |- |''[[On the Far Side of the Cadillac Desert With Dead Folks]]'' || [[Joe R. Lansdale|Lansdale, Joe R.]] ||1989|| A bounty hunter chases his quarry in a land where the "dead folks" have re-animated due to a bacterium which has escaped a lab. |- |''[[On Stranger Tides]]'' || [[Tim Powers|Powers, Tim]] ||1988||Puppeteer John Chandagnac, who was sailing to Jamaica, has no choice but to join the buccaneers who have taken him prisoner. Blackbeard is assembling an empire of ruthless navy of pirates, living and undead, to voyage to the fabled Fountain of Youth. John, now known as Jack Shandy, tries to free himself from Blackbeard's deadly supernatural domination. |- |''[[Patient Zero: A Joe Ledger Novel]]''||[[Jonathan Maberry|Maberry, Jonathan]]||2009|| A radical Middle Eastern terrorist group plans to release a deadly bio-weapon on the American people. |- |''[[Pontypool Changes Everything]]'' || [[Tony Burgess (author)|Burgess, Tony]] ||1998||The dark side of humanity as an epidemic virus terrorizes the earth. |- |''[[Pride and Prejudice and Zombies]]''||[[Seth Grahame-Smith|Grahame-Smith, Seth]]||2009||[[Mashup (book)|Mashup]] combining [[Jane Austen|Jane Austen's]] classic 1813 novel ''[[Pride and Prejudice]]'' with elements of modern zombie fiction.{{cite news |title= Pride and Prejudice, Now With Zombies! |url=http://www.time.com/time/arts/article/0,8599,1889075,00.html |date=2009-04-02 |accessdate= 2009-04-04 | work=Time |first=Lev | last=Grossman}} |- |''[[Pride and Prejudice and Zombies: Dawn of the Dreadfuls]]'' || [[Steve Hockensmith|Hockensmith, Steve]] || 2010 || Prequel to ''Pride and Prejudice and Zombies''. |- |''[[Pride and Prejudice and Zombies: Dreadfully Ever After]]'' || [[Steve Hockensmith|Hockensmith, Steve]] || 2011 || Sequel to ''Pride and Prejudice and Zombies''. |- |''Le protocole Reston''|| [[:fr:Mathieu Fortin|Mathieu Fortin]] ||2009|| In the city of Trois-Rivières, a mutant Asian monster escapes from a boat and a zombie outbreak begins. The governments try to keep the story from the media while a high school teacher and his roommate try to survive to their zombie neighbour. |- |''Raising Stony Mayhall'' || [[Daryl Gregory|Gregory, Daryl]]||2011||Set in 1968, after the first zombie apocalypse, the body of a teenage mother is discovered in the snow, clutching a dead baby. The dead child begins to grow. |- |''[[Resident Evil (series)#Novels|Resident Evil: Caliban Cove]]'' ||[[S.D. Perry|Perry, S.D.]]||1998 || A paramilitary force investigates an Umbrella cover facility. |- |''[[Resident Evil (series)#Novels|Resident Evil: City of the Dead]]'' ||[[S.D. Perry|Perry, S.D.]] ||1999 || Adaptation of ''[[Resident Evil 2]]''. |- |''[[Resident Evil (series)#Novels|Resident Evil: Code Veronica]]'' ||[[S.D. Perry|Perry, S.D.]]||1998 || Adaptation of ''[[Resident Evil (1996 video game)|Resident Evil]]''. |- |''[[Resident Evil (series)#Novels|Resident Evil: Underworld]]'' ||[[S.D. Perry|Perry, S.D.]]||1999|| A monster-creation lab is targeted for destruction. |- |''[[Resident Evil (series)#Novels|Resident Evil: Zero Hour]]''||[[S.D. Perry|Perry, S.D.]]||2004 || Adaption of ''[[Resident Evil 0]]''. |- |''[[The Rising (Keene novel)|The Rising]]''||[[Brian Keene|Keene, Brian]]||2004||Demons possess the bodies of the dead, including animals. One man attempts to reach his son. |- |''[[The Sacrifice (Higson novel)|The Sacrifice]]''||[[Charlie Higson]]||2012|| A post-apocalyptic young adult horror novel and the fourth book in a planned seven-book series, titled ''[[The Enemy (Higson novel)|The Enemy]]''. |- |''[[The Stupidest Angel: A Heartwarming Tale of Christmas Terror]]''|| [[Christopher Moore (author)|Moore, Christopher]]||2004||In his inept attempt to bring "Santa" back to life, an angel causes the townspeople of Pine Cove to fall under siege by brain-hungry zombies who arise from their burial plots. |- |''[[Undead]]''||[[John A. Russo|Russo, John A.]]||2010||A novelization of ''Night of the Living Dead'' and a sequel called ''Return of the Living Dead''. |- |''The Undead: Zombie Anthology''||D. L. Snell (Editor), Elijah Hall (Editor), [[Eric Shapiro]] (Contributor) ||2005|| Collection of 23 stories. Classic tales of survival in a world populated by the living dead as well as an array of unique takes on the zombie genre from authors including [[David Wellington (author)|David Wellington]] and [[David Moody]]{{cite book|title=The Undead: Zombie Anthology|authors=D.L. Snell (Editor), Elijah Hall (Editor), Eric Shapiro (Contributor)|year=2005| publisher=Permuted Press|ISBN= 978-0976555940 }} |- |''Under a Graveyard Sky''||[[John Ringo|Ringo, John]] ||2013|| The story of a family escaping a zombie epidemic in the US on a sailboat and the beginning of the process of finding survivors on the high seas as a prelude to retaking the mainland. Book one of the Black Tide Rising series. |- |''[[The Walking Dead: Rise of the Governor]]''||[[Robert Kirkman|Kirkman, Robert]] and [[Jay Bonansinga|Bonasinga, Jay]]||2011|| It depicts the journey of Philip Blake in the early days of the undead apocalypse to his eventual rise as "The Governor" of Woodbury. |- |''[[The Walking Dead: The Road to Woodbury]]''||[[Robert Kirkman|Kirkman, Robert]] and [[Jay Bonansinga|Bonasinga, Jay]]||2012|| It follows the travails of Lilly Caul who finds herself coming in contact with the "Governor" of Woodbury, a refuge amongst the zombie apocalypse that is not what it seems. The second of a planned trilogy. |- |''[[Warm Bodies]]''||[[Isaac Marion|Marion, Isaac]]||2010||R is a zombie who is a little different than his fellow Dead. He meets Julie Grigio, a Living girl, and ends up falling in love. |- |''[[World War Z]]'' || [[Max Brooks|Brooks, Max]]||2007||An oral history told by many survivors of the start, during, and aftermath of the zombie apocalypse.{{cite web |url=http://www.eatmybrains.com/showfeature.php?id=55 |title=Exclusive Interview: Max Brooks on World War Z |work=Eat My Brains! |date=October 20, 2006 |accessdate=April 26, 2008 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.untitledbooks.com/features/features/the-end-of-the-world-as-we-know-it/ |title=The End of the World as We Know it |accessdate=September 21, 2008 |last=Currie |first=Ron |date=September 5, 2008 |work=Untitled Books}} |- |''[[Darren Shan#Zom-B|Zom-B]]''||[[Darren Shan|Shan, Darren]]||2012||When news reports start appearing of a zombie outbreak in Ireland, B Smith's racist father thinks it is a joke—but even if it is not, he figures, it is ok to lose a few Irish. When zombies attack B's school, B is forced on a mad dash through the serpentine corridors, making allegiances with anyone with enough guts to fight off their pursuers. |- |''[[Zom-B: Angels]]''||[[Darren Shan|Shan, Darren]]||2013||The fourth book in the Zom-B series. B finds refuge with Angels, a group of teenagers who are dedicated to the task of restoring order back to the living. They are led by a mysterious, kindly doctor who can answer many of the questions that have been thrown up so far in the series. |- |''[[Zom-B: Baby]]''||[[Darren Shan|Shan, Darren]]||2013||The fifth book in the Zom-B series. B is trying to settle into life with the Angels, but finds it hard to believe some of Dr. Oystein's claims. When she decides to seek refuge elsewhere, she scours the streets of London in search of a place to call home. Wwhat she finds will lead B to question everything that she has ever held to be true. |- |''[[Zom-B: City]]''||[[Darren Shan|Shan, Darren]]||2013||The third book in the Zom-B series. B explores the streets of London, where we get our first glimpses of what has happened to the world in the wake of the zombie attacks. |- |''[[Zom-B: Gladiator]]''||[[Darren Shan|Shan, Darren]]||2014||The sixth book in the Zom-B series. B Smith has decided to live — and to fight for good as long as possible. However, London is overridden with the brain-eating undead and swarming with human mercenaries whose sense of right and wrong dissolved when society did. When they lay a trap, B is captured. And it will take dozens of battles—and the fight of a lifetime—to escape. |- |''[[Zom-B: Mission]]''||[[Darren Shan|Shan, Darren]]||2014||The seventh book in the Zom-B series. B Smith and the other Angels receive their first mission - to safely escort a group of human survivors from the zombie-infested streets of London to New Kirkham, a barricaded safe haven in the country. But after battling through crowds of undead monsters, B discovers that the survivors of the town do not necessarily represent the best of humanity... |- |''[[Zom-B: Underground]]''||[[Darren Shan|Shan, Darren]]||2013||The second book in the Zom-B series. Waking up in an underground military complex, months after the zombie outbreak, B has no memory of the last few months. As B learns more about the zombies held in the complex, and the scientists keeping them captive, unease settles in. |- |''[[Zombie Apocalypse!]]''||[[Stephen Jones (author)|Jones, Stephen]]||2010|| A [[mosaic novel]] in which interconnected narratives create a unique vision of the end of the world brought about by a plague. |- |''[[Zombie Apocalypse! Fightback]]''||[[Stephen Jones (author)|Jones, Stephen]]||2012|| The sequel to ''Zombie Apocalypse!'' The human fightback against the legions of the walking dead begins. |- |''[[The Zombie Survival Guide]]''||[[Max Brooks|Brooks, Max]]||2003||An earnest discussion of various survival techniques in a world threatened by zombies. |- |''[[Zombies: A Record of the Year of Infection]]''||[[Don Roff|Roff, Don]]||2009|| A man writes in his bird watching journal about trying to survive in a zombie apocalypse. |- |''[[Zone One]]''||[[Colson Whitehead|Whitehead, Colson]]||2011||Mark Spitz is a "sweeper," clearing away stragglers from Manhattan's Zone One district after the zombie attacks. These trapped souls are malfunctioning zombies, destined to ceaselessly repeat mundane acts they carried out while alive. |- |} ==Nonfiction== {|class="wikitable sortable" ! Name !! Author !! Year |- |''Gospel of the Living Dead: George Romero's Visions of Hell on Earth'' |[[Kim Paffenroth|Paffenroth, Kim]] |2006 |- |''Theories of International Politics and Zombies'' |[[Daniel W. revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{advert|date=January 2013}} {{unreferenced|date=August 2012}} }}
The '''MPEG Industry Forum''' ('''MPEGIF''') is a [[non-profit]] [[consortium]] dedicated to ''"further the adoption of [[MPEG]] Standards, by establishing them as well accepted and widely used standards among creators of content, developers, manufacturers, providers of services, and end users."''
The group is involved in many tasks, including promotion of [[MPEG]] standards (particularly [[MPEG-4]], [[MPEG-4 AVC]] / [[H.264]], [[MPEG-7]] and [[MPEG-21]]); developing MPEG certification for products; organising educational events; and collaborating on development of new ''[[de facto]]'' MPEG standards.
MPEGIF, founded in 2000,{{Citation needed|date=January 2013}} has played a significant role in facilitating the widespread adoption and deployment of MPEG-4 AVC/H.264 as the industry’s standard video compression technology powering next generation television and most mainstream content delivery and consumption applications including packaged media.{{Citation needed|date=January 2013}} MPEGIF serves as a single point of information on technology, products and services for these standards, offers interoperability testing, a conformance program, marketing activities and is supporting over 50 international trade shows and conferences per year.
The key activities of the forum are structured via three main Committees:
* Technology & Engineering * Interoperability & Compliance * Marketing & Communication
==2009–2010 focus areas== * 3DTV * Addressable advertising: extension and adoption of CableLabs SCTE-104 for all multimedia * MPEG-4/Scalable Video Coding (SVC) * Simplifying competitive licensing * Quality of Experience / Quality of Service metrics * Royalty free DRM initiatives * Online Video / Internet Streaming * IPTV ecosystem * Ultra HD (7680x4320) * MPEG/High-Performance Video Coding (HVC, H.265) * MPEG-7 / MPEG-21
MPEGIF is also running the [https://web.archive.org/web/20080314162519/http://logo.mpegif.org/ MPEGIF Logo Qualification Program], which is designed to help guide interoperability among products and technology. The program, based on a self-certification process, is free of charge and open to all companies using MPEG technology, not just members of MPEGIF although, membership is encouraged. Qualified products have the right to display the MP4 Qualification Mark and also list their status in their documentation, literature, and advertising. They will also have their product listed in the MPEGIF Product Directory.
In June 2012 the MPEG Industry Forum officially "declared victory" and voted to close its operation and merge its remaining assets with that of the [[Open IPTV Forum]].
== External links == *{{official website|http://www.mpegif.org/}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20040830162422/http://www.mpegif.org/ site at archive.org]
[[Category:MPEG]] [[Category:Digital television]] [[Category:History of television]] [[Category:Film and video technology]] [[Category:Standards organizations]] [[Category:High-definition television]] [[Category:Video compression]] [[Category:Videotelephony]]

{{Refimprove||date=July 2010}} [[File:Marquise de Créquy.jpg|thumb|Victoire, marquise de Créquy]] '''Renée-Caroline-''Victoire'' de Froulay de Tessé, marquise de Créquy de Heymont de Canaples d'Ambrières''' (1704–1803), was a French woman of letters, by marriage a member of the [[Créquy family]], which counted several distinguished public servants and prelates, particularly in the 16th, 17th and 18th centuries.{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}} The ''Souvenirs de la Marquise de Créquy'' is attributed to her by university librarians.<ref>http://penelope.uchicago.edu/crequy/index.shtml</ref>
In her ''Souvenirs'', which consists mainly of accurate noble genealogies and court gossip from the reigns of [[Louis XIV]], [[Louis XV]], [[Louis XVI]] and [[Napoleon]], there is a tale for which the author of the ''Souvenirs'' is the sole authority. This story, widely believed in France,{{Citation needed|date=December 2010}} is her statement, with a detailed story to back it up, that Britain's national anthem, "[[God Save the Queen]]", was in fact written by [[Jean-Baptiste Lully|Lully]] and sung by a French girls' school to greet Louis XIV.{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}} The French author of ''Souvenirs'' further states that the tune was later plagiarized by [[Handel]] and sold to the British crown as their [[Royal anthem|anthem]].<ref>[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/crequy/chap104.html#God_save_the_king ''Souvenirs'', Vol. I, Chapter IV]</ref>
If it is true, as some have claimed,{{Citation needed|date=December 2010}} that the story about the sale of the anthem is actually from a much later tabloid, then this anachronism is a reason why the author of ''Souvenirs'' is sometimes placed in the company of forgers, alongside the authors of such works as the ''[[Historia Augusta]]'', ''[[De Situ Britanniae]]'', and [[Annio of Viterbo]].{{Citation needed|date=December 2010}} If, on the other hand, the French tabloids of the 1850s published Madame de Créquy's story based on her memoirs, it's possible she believed the story to be true, or that the story is true.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k204968c Facsimiles furnished by Gallica Bibliothèque numérique in France] * {{Internet Archive author |sname=Marquise de Créquy |sopt=w}} *[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/crequy/index.shtml ''Souvenirs de la Marquise de Créquy''] (Original text, in French) *[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Gazetteer/People/Marquise_de_Crequy/home.html Brief selections, translated into English]
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Crequy, Froulay, Victoire De}} [[Category:1704 births]] [[Category:1803 deaths]] [[Category:18th-century French writers]] [[Category:Créquy family]] [[Category:French memoirists]] [[Category:Literary forgeries]] [[Category:Women memoirists]] [[Category:18th-century French women writers]]
{{France-noble-stub}}

{{Redirect-distinguish|Pioneer Entertainment|Pioneer Pictures}} {{globalize|date=February 2009}} {{Infobox company | name = NBCUniversal Entertainment Japan | logo = NBCUNiversal Entertainment Japan Logo.png | logo_size = 400px | type = [[Gōdō gaisha]]
[[Subsidiary]] | foundation = March, 1981 (as Pioneer LDC)
October, 2003 (as Geneon Entertainment)
February, 2009 (as Geneon Universal Entertainment)
December, 2013 (as NBCUniversal Entertainment Japan) | founder = [[Pioneer Corporation]]
[[JVC Kenwood Victor Entertainment|Victor Entertainment]] | location = [[Minato, Tokyo|Minato]], [[Tokyo]], [[Japan]] | key_people = | num_employees = | area_served = [[Japan]] | industry = [[Mass media]] | revenue = | owner = [[NBCUniversal]]
([[Comcast|Comcast Corporation]]) | parent = [[Universal Pictures|Universal Pictures International Entertainment]] | divisions = [[Universal Pictures Home Entertainment]]
[[Paramount Home Media Distribution|Paramount Home Media Distribution Japan]] | subsid = | products = [[Anime]], [[Film]], [[Music]] | homepage = {{URL|http://www.nbcuni.co.jp/}} }} {{Nihongo|'''NBCUniversal Entertainment Japan LLC'''|NBCユニバーサル・エンターテイメントジャパン合同会社|Enubīshī Yunibāsaru Entāteimento Japan Gōdō-gaisha}} (formerly known as '''Geneon Universal Entertainment''' and previously '''Pioneer LDC''' – Pioneer LaserDisc Company, a former subsidiary of [[Pioneer Corporation]]) is a Japanese music, [[anime]] and home entertainment production and distribution enterprise headquartered in [[Akasaka, Tokyo|Akasaka]], [[Minato, Tokyo|Minato]], Tokyo, Japan. From its days as Geneon Universal Entertainment, Geneon has been involved in the production and distribution of several anime in Japan. Geneon's North American branch (founded as Pioneer Entertainment) specialized in translating and distributing anime and related merchandise, such as [[soundtrack]]s across the region. Geneon is a [[portmanteau]] of the English words, '''gen'''erate and '''eon'''. On February 1, 2009, Geneon merged with [[Universal Pictures|Universal Pictures Japan]] into Geneon Universal Entertainment. On December 9, 2013, the company changed its name to the current NBCUniversal Entertainment Japan. Outside Japan, the majority of NBCUniversal Entertainment Japan's anime titles are distributed by Universal Sony Pictures Home Entertainment Australia in the Oceanic region, Universal Pictures in the UK and Ireland, and Universal Pictures Home Entertainment in North America. ==History== {{More citations needed|section|date=March 2014}} NBCUniversal Entertainment was formed under the name '''Pioneer LDC''' in 1981, related to Pioneer's Laserdisc business - originally Universal Pioneer, a joint venture with MCA Discovision. [[File:Geneon.svg|thumb|290px|Former logo for Geneon Entertainment from October 2003 to February 1, 2009]] In July 2003, the company was acquired by Japanese advertising and marketing company firm [[Dentsu]] and renamed to '''Geneon Entertainment''', while its North American division, Pioneer Entertainment, was renamed to '''Geneon USA'''.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2003-07-21/dentsu-acquires-pioneer |title=Dentsu acquires Pioneer - News |publisher=Anime News Network |date=2013-11-01 |accessdate=2013-11-05}} ===Geneon USA=== Geneon had signed a deal with [[Viz Media]] (then known as Viz Communications) to release their properties to DVD such as ''[[Pokémon (anime)|Pokémon]]'' and ''[[Ranma ½]]'' before Viz began producing their own DVDs.{{Citation needed|date=October 2013}} In November 2004, Geneon USA signed a deal with [[Toei Animation]] to distribute some of their titles into the North American market.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/press-release/2004-11-11/geneon-entertainment-signs-distribution-agreement-with-toei-animation |title=Geneon Entertainment Signs Distribution Agreement with Toei Animation |publisher=Anime News Network |date=2013-11-01 |accessdate=2013-11-05}} Launching titles included ''[[Air Master]]'', [[Interlude (visual novel)|''Interlude'']], and ''[[Slam Dunk (manga)|Slam Dunk]]''. However, in late 2006, the deal ended and all of the released titles went out of print.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2006-09-18/toei-dvds-cancelled |title=Toei DVDs Cancelled - News |publisher=Anime News Network |date=2013-11-01 |accessdate=2013-11-05}} In March 2007, Geneon became the exclusive North American distributor for [[Bandai Visual#Bandai Visual USA|Bandai Visual USA]].{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2007-03-05/bandai-visual-usa-new-licenses-and-distribution-deal |title=Bandai Visual USA new licenses and distribution deal - News |publisher=Anime News Network |date=2013-11-01 |accessdate=2013-11-05}} Four months later, it was announced that [[A.D. Vision#ADV Films|ADV Films]] would take over the distribution, marketing, and sales of Geneon USA's properties in the United States, starting October 1, 2007. According to the announcement, Geneon USA would continue to acquire, license, and produce English subs and dubs of anime for release in North America.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2007-08-24/adv-takes-over-geneon-sales-marketing-and-distribution |title=ADV Takes Over Geneon's Sales, Marketing, Distribution - News |publisher=Anime News Network |date=2013-11-01 |accessdate=2013-11-05}} However, the deal was canceled in September before it was implemented, with neither company giving details as to why beyond stating they were "unable to reach a mutual agreement."{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2007-09-20/adv-films-geneon-entertainment-distribution-deal-cancelled |title=ADV Films, Geneon USA's Distribution Deal Cancelled (Updated) - News |publisher=Anime News Network |date=2013-11-01 |accessdate=2013-11-05}}{{cite press release |title=Geneon USA Withdraws Appointment of Anime DVD Distribution Business to A.D. Vision |publisher=[[Dentsu]] |date=September 21, 2007 |accessdate=November 14, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071115014407/http://www.dentsu.com/news/2007/pdf/2007064-0921.pdf|archivedate=November 15, 2007|url=http://www.dentsu.com/news/2007/pdf/2007064-0921.pdf|format=PDF}} On December 3, Geneon USA closed distribution operations,{{Citation needed|date=November 2013}} with titles solicited through November 5 shipped. Titles that were in mid-release or licensed but unreleased were left in limbo.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2007-09-26/geneon-usa-to-cancel-dvd-sales-distribution-by-friday |title=Geneon USA to Cancel DVD Sales, Distribution by Friday - News |publisher=Anime News Network |date=2013-11-01 |accessdate=2013-11-05}} The Bandai Visual USA titles that were being distributed by Geneon were not affected by this closure, though some were delayed while Bandai Visual found a new distributor.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/press-release/2007-09-27/bandai-visual-usa-continues-to-release-new-titles-as-scheduled |title=Bandai Visual USA Continues to Release New Titles as Scheduled |publisher=[[Anime News Network]] |date=September 27, 2007 |accessdate=January 4, 2016}} Another North American anime company, [[Funimation Entertainment]], began negotiating with Geneon USA to distribute some of the company's licensed titles.{{cite web|url=http://www.icv2.com/articles/home/12043.html |title=Navarre/FUNimation Interested in Some Geneon Titles |publisher=ICv2 |date= |accessdate=2013-11-05}} In July 2008, a formal arrangement was announced and Funimation acquired the rights to "manufacture, sell, and distribute" various Geneon anime and live-action titles.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2008-07-03/funimation-agrees-to-distribute-select-geneon-titles |title=Funimation Agrees to Distribute Select Geneon Titles - News |publisher=Anime News Network |date=2013-11-01 |accessdate=2013-11-05}}{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/press-release/2008-07-03/funimation-entertainment-and-geneon-entertainment-sign-exclusive-distribution-agreement-for-north-america |title=FUNimation Entertainment and Geneon Entertainment Sign Exclusive Distribution Agreement for North America |publisher=Anime News Network |date=2013-11-01 |accessdate=2013-11-05}} Former Geneon USA titles has since been re-licensed by other companies such as [[Funimation]], [[Aniplex of America]], [[Sentai Filmworks]], [[Media Blasters]], [[Discotek Media]], [[Right Stuf Inc.|Nozomi Entertainment]], [[Section23 Films#Maiden Japan|Maiden Japan]], [[Viz Media]], [[Nippon Ichi Software|NIS America]], [[Pony Canyon|Ponycan USA]] and [[Universal Pictures Home Entertainment]]. ===Sale to Universal=== [[File:Geneonuniversal.jpg|180px|thumb|right|Former logo for Geneon Universal used from February 1, 2009, to December 9, 2013, before it became NBCUniversal Entertainment Japan.]] On November 12, 2008, Dentsu announced that it was selling 80.1% of its ownership in the company to [[NBCUniversal]]'s Universal Pictures International Entertainment (UPI), who planned to merge the company with its Universal Pictures Japan division to form a new company.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2008-11-12/geneon-to-merge-with-universal-pictures-japan |title=Geneon to Merge with Universal Pictures Japan - News |publisher=Anime News Network |date=2013-11-01 |accessdate=2013-11-05}} The merger closed on February 1, 2009,{{Citation needed|date=October 2013}} with the new company now known '''Geneon Universal Entertainment Japan'''.{{cite web|url=http://www.geneonuniversal.jp/ |title=Geneon Universal Entertainment |publisher=Geneonuniversal.jp |date= |accessdate=2013-11-05}} On December 9, 2013, the company once again changed its name to '''NBCUniversal Entertainment Japan'''.{{cite web|title=Geneon Universal Ent. Japan is Now Known as NBCUniversal Entertainment Japan|url=http://www.geneonuniversal.jp/core_sys/images/news/00000008/base/003.pdf|publisher=NBCUniversal Entertainment Japan|accessdate=9 December 2013|language=Japanese|format=PDF}} ===Purchase of Paramount Japan=== On January 1, 2016, the home entertainment portion of Paramount Japan was purchased by NBCUniversal in Japan.{{cite web|url=https://ssl.paramount.jp/close/pcs/|title=サイト閉鎖のお知らせ|trans-title=Site Closure Notification|language=Japanese|publisher=Paramount Japan|date=January 1, 2016|accessdate=May 22, 2016|archivedate=May 22, 2016|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6hhXmhJ7m}} ==Reception== In 2006, Geneon USA was named "Best Anime Company" by the Society for the Promotion of Japanese Animation.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/press-release/2007-06-13/akimbo-adds-geneon-to-its-acclaimed-anime-on-demand-collection |title=Akimbo Adds Geneon to Its Acclaimed Anime on Demand Collection |publisher=Anime News Network |date=2013-11-01 |accessdate=2013-11-05}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.nbcuni.co.jp/}} {{ja}} * {{ann|company|12727|NBCUniversal Entertainment Japan}} * {{ann|company|8953|Geneon Universal Entertainment}} * {{ann|company|2151|Geneon Entertainment}} * {{ann|company|1782|Geneon USA}} {{NBC Universal}} [[Category:NBCUniversal Entertainment Japan| ]] [[Category:Entertainment companies of Japan]] [[Category:Media companies based in Tokyo]] [[Category:Anime companies]] [[Category:Entertainment companies established in 1981]] [[Category:Media companies established in 1981]] [[Category:1981 establishments in Japan]] [[Category:Former Vivendi subsidiaries]] [[Category:NBCUniversal]]

{{Infobox website | name = Now I Know | logo = NowIKnow.png | screenshot = | screenshot_size = 250 | caption = | url = {{URL|www.nowiknow.com}} | commercial = | type = Newsletter | owner = Dan Lewis | launch date = 2010 | current status = Active }} '''Now I Know''' is a daily email newsletter about trivia written by Dan Lewis. Described as "a newer, less snarky iteration of Cecil Adams’ [[The Straight Dope]]," it has been running since 2010 with over 100,000 subscribers as of 2018.<ref name="Adweek2012">{{cite web | title=‘Now I Know’ Author is Real Person, and That’s How the E-Newsletter Works – Adweek | website=Adweek – Breaking News in Advertising, Media and Technology | date=2012-09-10 | url=https://www.adweek.com/digital/now-i-know-real-person-e-newsletter-success/ | access-date=2018-11-28}}</ref><ref name="kottke.org">{{cite web | last = Kottke| first= Jason|title=And if you don’t know, now you know | website=kottke.org | url=https://kottke.org/13/08/and-if-you-dont-know-now-you-know-dan-lewis | access-date=2018-11-28}}</ref> The newsletter won a [[Webby Award]] for email newsletters in 2013 and 2014.<ref name="The Webby Awards 2013">{{cite web | title=Now I Know | website=The Webby Awards | date=2010-01-01 | url=https://www.webbyawards.com/winners/2013/web/general-website/email-newsletters/now-i-know/ | access-date=2018-11-28}}</ref><ref name="The Webby Awards">{{cite web | title=Email Newsletters | website=The Webby Awards | url=https://www.webbyawards.com/winners/2014/web/general-website/email-newsletters/ | access-date=2018-11-30}}</ref> Lewis credits his success to his engagement with his community, claiming he replies to nearly every email sent to him.<ref name="Adweek2012" /> He also notes his Jewish background saying "[T]here's an oral tradition in Judaism to explain and analyze things" which is the general theme of his newsletter which uses seemingly obscure facts to tell a bigger story.<ref name="Goldenberg 2013">{{cite web | last=Goldenberg | first=Anna | title=Dan Lewis Is Obsessed With Knowing It All | website=The Forward | date=2013-11-04 | url=https://forward.com/culture/186542/dan-lewis-is-obsessed-with-knowing-it-all/ | access-date=2018-11-28}}</ref>
The newsletter has been turned into two books, ''Now I Know: The Revealing Stories Behind the World’s Most Interesting Facts'' and ''Now I Know More: The Revealing Stories Behind Even More of the World's Most Interesting Facts.''<ref name="Lewis 2013 p. ">{{cite book | last=Lewis | first=Dan | title=Now I know : the revealing stories behind the world's most interesting facts | publisher=Adams Media Corporation | publication-place=Avon, Mass | year=2013 | isbn=1-4405-6362-4 | oclc=833574784 | page=}}</ref><ref name="Lewis 2014 p. ">{{cite book | last=Lewis | first=Dan | title=Now I know more : the revealing stories from behind even more of the world's most interesting facts | publisher=Adams Media | publication-place=Avon, Massachusetts | year=2014 | isbn=978-1-4405-8215-8 | oclc=891941732 | page=}}</ref> The newsletter is also being expanded to a YouTube series featuring Matt Silverman. <ref name="Blazenhoff 2018">{{cite web | last=Blazenhoff | first=Rusty | title=New webseries by daily trivia newsletter 'Now I Know' | website=Boing Boing | date=2018-11-18 | url=https://boingboing.net/2018/11/18/new-webseries-by-daily-trivia.html | access-date=2018-11-28}}</ref> Topics in the newsletter range from to topical coverage such as the history of collect calling in the United States, to where the fear of poisoned Halloween candy comes from.<ref name="NIK124">{{cite web | title=The Battle Over the Collect Call - Now I Know | website=Now I Know | Learn Something New Every Day, By Email by Dan Lewis | date=2018-10-17 | url=http://nowiknow.com/the-battle-over-the-collect-call/ | access-date=2018-11-30}}</ref><ref name="NIK124b">{{cite web | title=Where Did the Fear of Poisoned Halloween Candy Come From? - Now I Know | website=Now I Know | Learn Something New Every Day, By Email by Dan Lewis | date=2018-10-31 | url=http://nowiknow.com/where-did-the-fear-of-poisoned-halloween-candy-come-from/ | access-date=2018-11-30}}</ref>
Lewis is a lawyer and co-founder of [[Wikia#ArmchairGM|ArmchairGM]], which was purchased by [[Wikia]]. He was an early [[blogger]] and is currently the Senior Director of Digital Marketing at [[Sesame Workshop]] where he used to tweet for [[Big Bird]] and started most of Sesame Street's social media accounts.<ref name="Goldenberg 2013" /><ref name="McKenzie 2012">{{cite web | last=McKenzie | first=Hamish | title=Why Old-School Email is the New-School Way To Find Out Cool Things | website=Pando | date=2012-05-29 | url=https://pando.com/2012/05/29/why-old-school-email-is-the-new-school-way-find-out-cool-things/ | access-date=2018-11-28}}</ref> Lewis was also the Connecticut State [[Magic the Gathering]] Champion in 1997.<ref name="Instagram 2016">{{cite web | title=Instagram post by Dan Lewis • Mar 24, 2016 at 2:44am UTC showing plaques| website=Instagram | date=2016-03-24 | url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BDUcfzhkw-w/ | access-date=2018-11-28}}</ref>
==External Links== * [http://nowiknow.com/ Official Website] * [http://dlewis.net/ Dan Lewis home page]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Newsletters]] [[Category:Trivia]]

{{Infobox artist | honorific_prefix = | name = Oscar Chichoni | honorific_suffix = | image = <!-- just the pagename, without the File:/Image: prefix or [[brackets]] --> | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different than name --> | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1957|07|14|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Corral de Bustos]], Argentina | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | nationality = [[Argentines|Argentine]] | residence = | education = | alma_mater = | known_for = illustration, [[conceptual art]], [[production designer]] | notable_works = | style = | movement = | spouse = | partner = | awards = <!-- {{awd|award|year|title|role|name}} (optional) --> | elected = | patrons = | memorials = | website = {{URL|chichoni.com}} | module = }}
'''Oscar Chichoni''' (born July 14, 1957) is an [[Argentina|Argentine]] illustrator of [[comic books]] and [[science fiction]] magazines and books.
==History== Chichoni was born in a desolate hamlet in [[Corral de Bustos]], [[Córdoba Province (Argentina)|province of Córdoba]], and is self-taught in art. He published his first comic books pictures at the age of 17 for the [[Argentina|Argentine]] publisher [[Editorial Record|Record]], and soon his work was paralleled to that of some famous authors like [[Alberto Breccia]], [[Juan Zanotto]] and [[Juan Giménez]].
Following this period as a comic book artist, Chichoni devoted himself to painting. He spent two times studying under the painter [[Álvaro Izurieta]], and began to draw book covers for several publishers, becoming soon renowned in all the world for his powerful and well-detailed anatomies.
In the second half of the 1980s he moved to [[Europe]], collaborating and winning various awards. His main collaboration is for the [[Italy|Italian]] editor [[Arnoldo Mondadori|Arnoldo Mondadori's]] science fiction series ''[[Urania (magazine)|Urania]]'' and its spin-offs.
Since 1995, Chichoni has been working as free-lance, mainly as ''conceptual creator'' for films. He collaborated on the graphic part of the videogames ''[[Starship Titanic]]'' by [[Douglas Adams]] and ''[[Broken Sword|Broken Sword 3]]''. He won an [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] as art director for the film ''[[Restoration (1995 film)|Restoration]]'' by [[Michael Hoffman (American director)|Michael Hoffman]]. In 2000 he published ''[[Mekanika]]'', his first collection of artworks.
Chichoni's best-known style combines mechanical intricacy and sensuality in a striking statement of Art Deco reborn. He is a man of many pencils, and is capable of countless other styles hard-edged, gothic, impressionist, almost anything that might fire the imagination.
Chichoni is currently living in [[London]], where he works in team with the architect [[Isabel Molina]].
==Awards== *In [[Argentina]], ''[[Premio Mas Alla]]'' as best illustrator. *In [[Spain]], ''[[Premio 1984]]'' as best cover artist and for the best cover. *In [[Italy]], ''Caran d'Ache'' at the Lucca Comics.
==Selected works==
===Covers=== * ''Fierro'' (Argentina) * ''[[Playboy]]'' (Argentine and Spanish edition) * ''Totem'' (Spain) * ''Minotauro'' (Argentina and Spain) * ''[[Zona 84]]'' (Spain) * ''[[Urania (magazine)|Urania]]'' (Italy) * ''[[Urania (magazine)|Classici Urania]]'' (Italy) * ''[[Altri Mondi]]'' (Italy) * ''[[L'Eternauta]]'' (Italy) * ''[[Métal hurlant]]'' magazine (France) * ''[[USA Magazine]] (France) * ''[[Heavy Metal (magazine)|Heavy Metal]]'' (USA)
===Films=== * ''[[Restoration (1995 film)|Restoration]]'' (1995) * ''[[Tell-Tale (film)|Tell-Tale]]'' (2009)
===Video games=== * ''[[Starship Titanic]]'' (1998) * ''[[Broken Sword|Broken Sword 3: the Sleeping Dragon]]'' (2003) * ''[[Necrocide: The Dead Must Die]]'' (cancelled)
==External links== * [http://www.chichoni.com Official website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060326150848/http://www.delos.fantascienza.com/delos33/chiconi.html Interview about "Starship Titanic" (in Italian)] * [http://www.net-cafe.hu/fantasy.php?pg=1&ct=99 Gallery of illustrations]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Chichoni, Oscar}} [[Category:1957 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Córdoba Province, Argentina]] [[Category:Argentine speculative fiction artists]] [[Category:Science fiction artists]] [[Category:Fantasy artists]] [[Category:Game artists]]

{{Italic title}} {{Infobox website | name = ''PopMatters'' | logo = Logo-popmatters.png | screenshot = | caption = | url = {{url|popmatters.com}} | commercial = | type = [[Online magazine]] | language = English | registration = | owner = Sarah Zupko | creator = Sarah Zupko | editor = Karen Zarker | launch date = {{start date and age|1999|10}} | alexa = {{Increase}} 39,639 ({{as of|2018|3|2|alt=March 2018}})<ref name="alexa">{{cite web|url= http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/popmatters.com|title=PopMatters Site Info|publisher=[[Alexa Internet]]}}</ref> | current status = Active | revenue = }} '''''PopMatters''''' is an international [[online magazine]] of cultural criticism that covers many aspects of [[popular culture]]. ''PopMatters'' publishes reviews, interviews, and detailed essays on most cultural products and expressions in areas such as [[music]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ideas.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/11/17/did-zach-braff-kill-american-music/|work=[[The New York Times]]|first=Chris|last=Milam|date=2009-11-17|accessdate=December 19, 2016|title=Did Zach Braff Kill American Music?}}</ref> [[television]], [[film]]s, [[book]]s, [[video game]]s, [[comics]], [[sports]], [[theater]], [[visual arts]], [[travel]], and the [[Internet]].<ref name="popmatters">{{cite web|url=http://www.popmatters.com/pm/about|website=PopMatters|title=About PopMatters}}</ref>
== History == ''PopMatters'' was founded by Sarah Zupko, who had previously established the cultural studies academic resource site PopCultures.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rockcriticsarchives.com/interviews/sarahzupko/sarahzupko.html |title=Sarah Zupko: Why Pop Matters |publisher=Rockcriticsarchives.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-13}}</ref> ''PopMatters'' launched in the fall of 1999<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.popmatters.com/72107-72091-decade-dense-the-60-most-memorable-films-of-19991-2496037835.html|title=Decade-Dense: The 60 Most Memorable Films of 1999 - PopMatters|work=PopMatters.com|date= |accessdate=2018-10-23}}</ref> as a sister site providing original essays, reviews and criticism of various media products. Over time, the site went from a weekly publication schedule to a five-day-a-week magazine format, expanding into regular reviews, features, and columns. In the fall of 2005, monthly readership exceeded one million.
From 2006 onward, ''PopMatters'' produced several syndicated newspaper columns for [[The McClatchy Company|McClatchy-Tribune News Service]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.editorandpublisher.com/PrintArticle/Partnership-for-McClatchy-and-PopMatters-com|title=Partnership for McClatchy and PopMatters.com|work=[[Editor & Publisher]]|date=2006-09-25}}</ref> As of 2009, there are four different pop culture related columns each week.
The PopMatters Book Imprint published ''Joss Whedon: The Complete Companion'', edited by Mary Money, with [[Titan Books]] in May 2012. The imprint also published four books in a series with Counterpoint/Soft Skull<ref>{{cite web|url=http://booksquare.com/soft-skull-and-popmatters-sitting-in-a-tree/ |title=Soft Skull and PopMatters Sitting In A Tree |publisher=Booksquare.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-13}}</ref> in 2008{{ndash}}2009 including ''China Underground'' by Zachary Mexico, ''Apocalypse Jukebox: The End of the World in American Popular Music'' by Edward Whitelock and David Janssen, ''Rebels Wit Attitude: Subversive Rock Humorists'' by Iain Ellis, and ''The Solitary Vice: Against Reading'' by [[Mikita Brottman]].
== Staff == ''PopMatters'' publishes content from contributors located around the globe, based in six continents and numerous countries. Its staff includes writers from various backgrounds, ranging from academics and professional journalists to career professionals and first time writers. Many of its writers are published authorities in various fields of study.<ref name="popmatters"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/10913650/ns/news/t/michael-e-ross/|work=[[MSNBC]]|title=Michael E. Ross MSNBC.com editor and correspondent}}</ref> Notable former contributors include [[David Weigel]], political reporter for ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'',<ref name="David Weigel">{{cite web|title=David Weigel|url=http://www.popmatters.com/pm/archive/contributor/29/|work=PopMatters|accessdate=25 March 2013}}</ref> [[Steven Hyden]], staff writer for ''[[Grantland]]'' and author of ''Whatever Happened To Alternative Nation?'',<ref>{{cite web|last=Hyden|first=Steven|title=An Interview with Doug Martsch|url=http://www.popmatters.com/pm/feature/martsch-doug-021015/|publisher=''PopMatters''|accessdate=25 March 2013}}</ref> and Rob Horning, executive editor of ''The New Inquiry''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Rob Horning|url=http://www.popmatters.com/pm/archive/contributor/68/|publisher=''PopMatters''|accessdate=25 March 2013}}</ref> Karen Zarker is the senior editor.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{official website}}

{{Unreferenced|date=May 2007}}
The '''Prix Suzanne Bianchetti''' is an award in [[France|French]] cinema given annually since 1937 to the most promising young film actress.
The award was created by writer and actor [[René Jeanne]] (1887-1969) who served as the director of ''L'Etablissement Cinématographique des Armées''. When his wife, actress [[Suzanne Bianchetti]] died in 1936 at the age of 47, he established an award dedicated to her memory to be given annually to the most promising young actress.
The award was given for the first time in 1937 to actress [[Junie Astor]] for her performance in the film [[Women's Club (film)|Women's Club]]. The award comes in the form of a medallion engraved with Suzanne Bianchetti's image. Since its inception, the Prix Suzanne Bianchetti has been awarded to many of the greatest names in French cinema who went on to national and international stardom.
==List of winners (incomplete)== *1937 – [[Junie Astor]] (''[[Women's Club (film)|Women's Club]]'', 1936) *1938 – [[Janine Darcey]] *1939 – [[Sylvia Bataille]] *1940 – [[Micheline Presle]] (''[[Girls in Distress]]'', 1939) *1941-1945 no award due to World War II *1947 – [[Simone Signoret]] *1948 – [[Odile Versois]] *1949 – [[Arlette Thomas]] *1950 – [[Christiane Lenier]] *1951 – [[Nadine Alari]] *1952 – [[Nadine Basile]] *1953 – [[Etchika Choureau]] (''L'Envers du paradis'', 1953) *1954 – [[Marina Vlady]] *1955 – [[Geneviève Kervine]] *1956 – [[Annie Girardot]] *1957 – [[Anne Doat]] *1958 – [[Pascale Petit (actress)|Pascale Petit]] (''[[One Life (1958 film)|One Life]]'', 1957) *1959 – [[Roger Dumas]] (awarded to a male actor) *1960 – [[Perrette Pradier]] *1961 – [[Renée Marie Potet]] *1962 – [[Corinne Marchand]] *1963 – [[Marie Dubois]] *1964 – [[Colette Castel]] *1965 – [[Macha Méril]] *1966 – [[Geneviève Bujold]] *1967 – [[Caroline Cellier]] (awarded for a stage performance in ''Pygmalion'') *1968 – [[Danièle Evenou]] *1970 – [[Ludmila Mikaël]] *1972 – [[Bulle Ogier]] *1974 – [[Isabelle Adjani]] (''La Gifle'', 1974) *1976 – [[Isabelle Huppert]] (''[[The Judge and the Assassin]]'', 1976) *1980 – [[Dominique Laffin]] *1986 – [[Juliette Binoche]] (''[[Mauvais Sang]]'', 1986) *1988 – [[Marianne Basler]] *1990 – [[Dominique Blanc]] *1991 – [[Anouk Grinberg]] *1993 – [[Charlotte Kady]] *1994 – [[Isabelle Carré]] *1995 – [[Clotilde Courau]] *1996 – [[Sandrine Kiberlain]] *1998 – [[Virginie Ledoyen]] *2000 – [[Audrey Tautou]] *2001 – [[Barbara Schulz]] *2002 – [[Françoise Gillard]] *2003 – [[Mélanie Doutey]] *2004 – [[Sara Forestier]] and [[Sophie Quinton]] *2005 – [[Chloé Lambert]] *2006 – [[Nathalie Boutefeu]] *2007 – [[Déborah François]] *2008 – [[Clotilde Hesme]] *2009 – [[Astrid Berges-Frisbey]] *2010 – [[Elodie Navarre]] *2011 – [[Anaïs Demoustier]] *2012 – [[Marie Kremer]] *2013 – [[Pauline Étienne]] *2014 – [[Adèle Haenel]] *2015 – [[Marine Vacth]] *2016 – [[Camille Cottin]] *2017 – [[Suliane Brahim]]
==References== *''Adapted from the article [https://web.archive.org/web/20070927195220/http://www.wikinfo.org/wiki.phtml?title=Prix_Suzanne_Bianchetti Prix Suzanne Bianchetti], from [[Wikinfo]], licensed under the [[GNU Free Documentation License]].''

revision.comment: Copying from [[Category:English trombonists]] to [[Category:Male trombonists]] using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Use British English|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Richard Jones | image = | image_size = | caption = Richard Jones in 2016 | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1990|09|21}} | birth_place = [[Leytonstone]], [[London]], UK | nationality = British | occupation = [[Soldier]], [[Magic (illusion)|magician]] | years_active = 2016–present }} '''Richard Jones''' (born 21 September 1990) is a British [[Magician (illusion)|magician]] and [[British Army|military]] [[soldier]], best known for winning the [[Britain's Got Talent (series 10)|tenth series]] of ''[[Britain's Got Talent]]'' in 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.itv.com/britainsgottalent/live-shows/is-your-britains-got-talent-2016-winner|title=Richard Jones is your Britain's Got Talent 2016 winner!|date=28 May 2016|publisher=[[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]|accessdate=28 May 2016}}</ref>
==Biography== Jones was born in [[Leytonstone]], London and grew up in [[Chigwell]], Essex.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gazette-news.co.uk/news/14516226.Magician_and_mind_reader_Richard_Jones_in_BGT_final/|title=BGT Champion 2016}}</ref><ref>[http://impossiblelive.com/the-company/lance-corporal-richard-jones Lance Corporal Richard Jones | Performers & Creatives | Impossible Official Website] Retrieved 2016-10-23.</ref> He joined the [[British Army]] in 2010 and studied for one year in [[Twickenham]] at the [[Royal Military School of Music]]. He lives in [[South Woodham Ferrers]].<ref>[http://www.itv.com/news/anglia/2016-05-29/britains-got-talent-magician-richard-jones-stuns-public-with-his-magic-act/ Britain's Got Talent: Magician Richard Jones stuns public with his magic act | Anglia - ITV News] Retrieved 2016-10-23.</ref>
He spent three years with the band of the [[Parachute Regiment (United Kingdom)|Parachute Regiment]] before being posted to the band of the [[Household Cavalry]] in 2014 as a mounted dutyman.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/tv-news/britains-talent-champ-richard-jones-8079535|title=Corporal Jones Britain's Got Talent 2016 winner!|date=28 May 2016|publisher=[[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]|accessdate=28 May 2016}}</ref>
On 15 March 2016, he appeared as a contestant on ITV's ''[[The Chase (UK game show)|The Chase]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rNL6CkJOqho|title=BGT Winner Richard Jones Dazzles Bradley With A Magic Trick - The Chase|first=|last=The Chase|date=15 March 2016|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref>
On 11 June 2016 Lance Corporal Jones performed as a bandsman in the [[Trooping the Colour]], as part of the 90th birthday celebrations of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II. He performed as a magician in the [[Royal Variety Performance]] at the [[Hammersmith Apollo]] in early December, in the presence of senior members of the [[British Royal Family]]. In April 2017, he had his own one-off show on ITV called ''Operation Magic''.
Jones toured the UK with his ''Power of Imagination'' tour which began in [[Windsor, Berkshire|Windsor]] in August 2017 and ended on the [[Isle of Wight]] in November 2017.<ref>http://www.richardjonesmagic.co.uk/tour-dates/</ref>
On 9 February 2018 it was confirmed that Jones would tour at [[Butlins]] holidays during half terms and summer holidays throughout 2018.<ref>https://www.butlins.com/pdfs/minehead-whatsonguide-6.pdf</ref>
